title: Full annual cycle bioenergetics model of migration for Galapagos tortoises
summary: This code was created to run a bioenergetics-based model of movement for Galapagos tortoises. It calculates energetic surplus or deficit at a daily time scale based on inputted temperature (6 times a day) and NDVI value (a single value per days), as well as the mass of an individual. It then uses dynamic programming to determine the optimal timing of movement between two foraging habitats, given time-series of NDVI in each habitat, and temperatures in both habitats and in a transition zone between habitats.  Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms): Full annual cycle bioenergetics model of migration for Galapagos tortoises Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)): Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including [...]
body:
This code was created to run a bioenergetics-based model of movement for Galapagos tortoises. It calculates energetic surplus or deficit at a daily time scale based on inputted temperature (6 times a day) and NDVI value (a single value per days), as well as the mass of an individual. It then uses dynamic programming to determine the optimal timing of movement between two foraging habitats, given time-series of NDVI in each habitat, and temperatures in both habitats and in a transition zone between habitats.

Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

Full annual cycle bioenergetics model of migration for Galapagos tortoises

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

This code was created to run a bioenergetics-based model of movement for Galapagos tortoises. It calculates energetic surplus or deficit at a daily time scale based on inputted temperature (6 times a day) and NDVI value (a single value per days), as well as the mass of an individual. It then uses dynamic programming to determine the optimal timing of movement between two foraging habitats, given time-series of NDVI in each habitat, and temperatures in both habitats and in a transition zone between habitats.

Originator(s) (Name(s) of the model developer(s)/author(s)):

Charles B Yackulic (USGS)

Contact Name(s) (Person(s) responsible for maintenance of the model):

Charles B Yackulic (USGS)

Contact Email(s):

cyackulic@usgs.gov

Release Date (Date model was originally released (MM, YYYY)):

2017

Last Update (Date of last update (MM, YYYY)):

Organization(s) (Organization(s) that produced, funded, or partnered on the creation of this model):

USGS

Mission Area (USGS mission area with which this model most clearly aligns. https://www.usgs.gov/science/mission-areas):

Ecosystems

License (OSI-approved (Open-Source Initiative) license (see https://opensource.org/licenses)):

https://doi.org/10.5066/F78K777N

Model Citation (How to cite the model  (e.g., Software Release citation). For example, Doe, J.S., Sea Turtle Cuteness Model, 2020, U.S. Geological Survey, https://doi.org/xxxxx)):

Yackulic, C.B., 2017, Full Annual Cycle Bioenergetics model of migration applied to Galapagos tortoises—Model: U.S. Geological Survey software release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F78K777N.

Identifier (Location where the model is posted or published (e.g. PID or DOI)):

https://doi.org/10.5066/F78K777N

Language (Computer language or platform used for programming (e.g., Fortan, R, Python)):

R

References (References (where the model has been cited, outputs, data release):

Yackulic, C.B., Blake, Stephen, and Bastille-Rousseau, Guillaume, 2017, Full annual cycle bioenergetics model of migration applied to Galapagos tortoises—Data: U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F7154F7P.

Resources (Resources (how to use the model, where to download it, related publications, other webpages about the model (in other catalogs), USGS webpage):

Yackulic, C.B., Blake, S. and Bastille‐Rousseau, G., 2017. Benefits of the destinations, not costs of the journeys, shape partial migration patterns. Journal of Animal Ecology, 86(4), pp.972-982, https://besjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/1365-2656.12679

Yackulic, C.B., 2017, Full Annual Cycle Bioenergetics model of migration applied to Galapagos tortoises—Model: U.S. Geological Survey software release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F78K777N.
